title: Royals steal the show in eye-catching fashion for Emperor Naruhito's enthronement in Japan
text:
Advertisement

Glamorous gowns, eye-catching hats and statement jewellery were the order of the day as stylish royals and First Ladies from around the world arrived in Tokyo for the enthroning of Japan's Emperor Naruhito.

Queen Letizia of Spain, Queen Maxima of the Netherlands and Queen Mathilde of Belgium were among 180 dignitaries who gathered to watch the centuries-old ceremony - and donned their finest formal wear for the occasion.

Crown Princess Mary of Denmark was the picture of elegance in a soft grey ensemble, while Crown Princess Victoria of Sweden plumped for a bold shade of purple.

Royal fashion runway! (left-right): Sweden's King Carl XVI Gustaf and Crown Princess Victoria; Queen Letizia of Spain; Queen Mathilde and King Philippe of Belgium were among the dignitaries who attended the enthroning of Japan's new emperor

Picture of elegance: Queen Maxima of the Netherlands, left, and Thailand's Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha, and his wife, Naraporn Chan-ocha, also attended the centuries-old ceremony today

Crown Princess Mary of Denmark looked beautiful in a soft grey ensemble as she took her seat between Prince Charles and Crown Prince Frederick of Denmark to attend the Enthronement Ceremony at the Imperial Palace in Tokyo

Japanese Emperor Naruhito formally ascended to the throne on Tuesday in a centuries-old ceremony inside the Pine Room at the Imperial Palace in Tokyo

Standing alongside the new Emperor during the ceremony was his wife, Empress Masako, who rarely takes part in royal ceremonies amid concerns for her health

Thailand's First Lady Naraporn Chan-ocha looked resplendent in traditional dress.

Naruhito became emperor and his wife Masako became empress on May 1 in a brief ceremony, but Tuesday's 'Sokui no Rei' was a more elaborate ritual at the royal palace in which he officially announced his change in status to the world.

'I swear that I will act according to the constitution and fulfil my responsibility as the symbol of the state and of the unity of the people,' the 59-year-old declared, his voice slightly hoarse, in front of about 2,000 guests, including Prince Charles.

Floral fancy! Queen Letizia of Spain looked typically stylish for the high-profile occasion, plumping for a pink and green floral gown from Spanish designer Matilde Cano, which she accessorised with a pretty blush pink headband

Warm greeting: Queen Letizia of Spain and Queen Maxima of the Netherlands embraced at the ceremony in Tokyo today

'I sincerely hope that Japan will develop further and contribute to the friendship and peace of the international community, and to the welfare and prosperity of human beings through the people's wisdom and ceaseless efforts.'

The first Japanese emperor born after World War Two, Naruhito acceded to the throne when his father, Akihito, became the first Japanese monarch to abdicate in two centuries after worrying that advancing age might make it hard to perform official duties.

Queen Letizia of Spain looked typically stylish for the high-profile occasion, plumping for a pink and green floral gown from Spanish designer Matilde Cano, which she accessorised with a pretty blush pink headband and a green waist belt to accentuate her svelte frame.

Never one to shy away from making a statement, the 47-year-old finished the look with glittering jewels at her neck and wrist.

The Netherlands' Queen Maxima made an entrance in a head-to-toe silver-grey look, arriving alongside her husband King Willem-Alexander.

The queen's floor-length gown featured floral applique and flattering sheer sleeves. She topped the ensemble with one of her signature hats in the same shimmering shade.
description: Glamorous gowns, eye-catching hats and statement jewellery were the order of the day as royals and First Ladies arrived in Tokyo for the enthroning of Japan's Emperor Naruhito today.
